message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Prosocial behavior and altruism: A review of concepts and definitions
Paper Abstract: The field of prosociality is flourishing, yet researchers disagree about how to define prosocial behavior and often neglect defining it altogether. In this review, we provide an overview about the breadth of definitions of prosocial behavior and the related concept of altruism. Common to almost all definitions is an emphasis on the promotion of welfare in agents other than the actor. However, definitions of the two concepts differ in terms of whether they emphasize intentions and motives, costs and benefits, and the societal context. In order to improve on the conceptual ambiguity surrounding the study of prosociality, we urge researchers to provide definitions, to use operationalizations that match their definitions, and to acknowledge the diversity of prosocial behavior.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Web search results for query: "Welfare"

Links: [{"title":"Welfare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare"},{"title":"Welfare state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_state"},{"title":"Welfare spending - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_spending"},{"title":"Welfare in Japan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_in_Japan"},{"title":"Welfare economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_economics"},{"title":"Welfare state in the United Kingdom - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_state_in_the_United_Kingdom"},{"title":"Welfare reform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_reform"},{"title":"Welfare in New York - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_in_New_York"},{"title":"Fundamental theorems of welfare economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_theorems_of_welfare_economics"},{"title":"Social welfare function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_welfare_function"}]

Here are the search results for "Welfare":

## Overview

Welfare spending is a type of government support intended to ensure that members of a society can meet basic human needs such as food and shelter. The term encompasses several related concepts:

**Welfare State**: A welfare state is a form of government in which the state (or a well-established network of social institutions) protects and promotes the economic and social well-being of its citizens, based upon the principles of equal opportunity, equitable distribution of wealth, and public responsibility.

**Broader Definition**: Welfare may also encompass efforts to provide a basic level of well-being through subsidized social services such as healthcare, education, infrastructure, vocational training, and public housing.

## Welfare Economics

Welfare economics is a field of economics that applies microeconomic techniques to evaluate the overall well-being (welfare) of a society.

## Historical Context

The first welfare state was Imperial Germany (1871–1918), where the Bismarck government introduced social security in 1889.(no content)The fullest forms of the welfare state were developed after World War II.

The search results provide extensive information on welfare systems, welfare economics, and welfare states across different countries and time periods.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Altruism"

Links: [{"title":"Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism"},{"title":"Effective altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_altruism"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Altruism theory of voting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_theory_of_voting"},{"title":"Pathological Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathological_Altruism"},{"title":"Effective Altruism Global - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_Altruism_Global"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)"},{"title":"Psychological barriers to effective altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_barriers_to_effective_altruism"},{"title":"Category:Organizations associated with effective altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Organizations_associated_with_effective_altruism"},{"title":"Parochial altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parochial_altruism"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about altruism:

## Definition and Meaning

Altruism is concern for the well-being, the life, of others, independently of personal benefit or reciprocity.(no content)Altruism may be considered a synonym of selflessness, the opposite of self-centeredness.

## Historical Background

The term was coined in the 19th century by the founding sociologist and philosopher of science Auguste Comte, and has become a major topic for psychologists (especially evolutionary psychology researchers), evolutionary biologists, and ethologists.(no content)He derived it from the Italian altrui, which in turn was derived from Latin alteri, meaning "other people" or "somebody else".

## Cultural Perspectives

Altruism is an important moral value in many cultures, ideologies, and religions. It can expand beyond care for humans to include consideration for other sentient beings and future generations.

## Effective Altruism

Effective altruism is the use of evidence and reason to determine the most effective ways to benefit others.(no content)Effective altruism (EA) is a 21st-century philosophical and social movement that advocates impartially calculating benefits and prioritizing causes to provide the greatest good.

## Biological Perspective

In biology, altruism is behaviour by an individual that increases the fitness of another individual while decreasing their own.(no content)Altruism in this sense is different from the philosophical concept of altruism, in which an action would only be called "altruistic" if it was done with the conscious intention of helping another. In the behavioural sense, there is no such requirement. As such, it is not evaluated in moral terms—it is the consequences of an action for reproductive fitness that determine whether the action is considered altruistic, not the intentions, if any, with which the action is performed.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Prosociality"

Links: [{"title":"Prosocial behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosocial_behavior"},{"title":"Helping behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helping_behavior"},{"title":"Social value orientations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_value_orientations"},{"title":"Sociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociality"},{"title":"Hyperprosociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperprosociality"},{"title":"Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism"},{"title":"Moral identity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_identity"},{"title":"Social preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_preferences"},{"title":"Talk:Prosocial behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Prosocial_behavior"},{"title":"Daniel Batson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Batson"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about prosociality:

## Definition

Prosocial behavior is a social behavior that "benefit[s] other people or society as a whole", "such as helping, sharing, donating, co-operating, and volunteering".(no content)The person may or may not intend to benefit others; the behavior's prosocial benefits are often only calculable after the fact.

## Motivations

These actions may be motivated by culturally influenced value systems; empathy and concern about the welfare and rights of others; egoistic or practical concerns, such as one's social status or reputation, hope for direct or indirect reciprocity, or adherence to one's perceived system of fairness; or altruism.

## Impact

Evidence suggests that prosociality is central to the well-being of social groups across a range of scales, including schools.(no content)Prosocial behavior in the classroom can have a significant impact on a student's motivation for learning and contributions to the classroom and larger community.

## Development

Children with responsive parents develop more empathy, prosociality, a moral self and conscience.

## Historical Context

The concept of prosocial behavior in psychology gained popularity in the 1970s. It was introduced to describe acts that promote positive social outcomes, such as cooperation and helping, and has since been examined through the lens of evolutionary biology, neuroscience, and cross-cultural psychology.

Links: [{"title":"Prosocial behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosocial_behavior"},{"title":"Helping behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helping_behavior"},{"title":"Social value orientations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_value_orientations"},{"title":"Sociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociality"},{"title":"Hyperprosociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperprosociality"},{"title":"Altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism"},{"title":"Moral identity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_identity"},{"title":"Social preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_preferences"},{"title":"Talk:Prosocial behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Prosocial_behavior"},{"title":"Daniel Batson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Batson"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about prosociality:

## Definition

Prosocial behavior is a social behavior that "benefit[s] other people or society as a whole", "such as helping, sharing, donating, co-operating, and volunteering".(no content)The person may or may not intend to benefit others; the behavior's prosocial benefits are often only calculable after the fact.

## Motivations

These actions may be motivated by culturally influenced value systems; empathy and concern about the welfare and rights of others; egoistic or practical concerns, such as one's social status or reputation, hope for direct or indirect reciprocity, or adherence to one's perceived system of fairness; or altruism.

## Impact

Evidence suggests that prosociality is central to the well-being of social groups across a range of scales, including schools.(no content)Prosocial behavior in the classroom can have a significant impact on a student's motivation for learning and contributions to the classroom and larger community.

## Development

Children with responsive parents develop more empathy, prosociality, a moral self and conscience.

## Historical Context

The concept of prosocial behavior in psychology gained popularity in the 1970s. It was introduced to describe acts that promote positive social outcomes, such as cooperation and helping, and has since been examined through the lens of evolutionary biology, neuroscience, and cross-cultural psychology.

Here's comprehensive information about prosocial behavior based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

Prosocial behavior was introduced to describe acts that promote positive social outcomes, such as cooperation and helping, and has since been examined through the lens of evolutionary biology, neuroscience, and cross-cultural psychology.(no content)The concept of prosocial behavior in psychology gained popularity in the 1970s.

## Motivations Behind Prosocial Behavior

These actions may be motivated by culturally influenced value systems; empathy and concern about the welfare and rights of others; egoistic or practical concerns, such as one's social status or reputation, hope for direct or indirect reciprocity, or adherence to one's perceived system of fairness; or altruism, though the existence of pure altruism is somewhat disputed.

## Key Types

Examples include altruism (helping others with no expectation of reciprocation), reciprocal altruism (helping others with the expectation that the favor may be returned), cooperation (working together toward shared goals), and volunteering and charitable giving (contributing time or resources to benefit others without compensation).

## Importance Across Settings

Evidence suggests that prosociality is central to the well-being of social groups across a range of scales, including schools, where prosocial behavior in the classroom can have a significant impact on a student's motivation for learning and contributions to the classroom and larger community.(no content)In the workplace, prosocial behavior can have a significant impact on team psychological safety, as well as positive indirect effects on employee's helping behaviors and task performance.

## Factors Influencing Prosocial Behavior

Empathy is a strong motive in eliciting prosocial behavior, and has deep evolutionary roots.

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey (literature review)

**Key Entities Extracted:**

1. **Prosocial behavior** (concept) - The central subject of the review, examining definitions and concepts across the field
2. **Altruism** (concept) - A related concept that the paper examines in relation to prosocial behavior
3. **Welfare** (concept) - A fundamental element emphasized across definitions as the promotion of welfare in others

All entities are marked as "uses" relations since this is a survey paper that reviews and analyzes existing concepts rather than proposing new ones. The validation passed successfully with all Wikipedia URLs verified.

- [Prosocial behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosocial_behavior)
